title: react dom doesn't leave white space in text when there is a line break followed by an inline element
body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?** Bug. **What is the current behavior?** React treats line breaks in text differently than how pure HTML does it. **How to reproduce:** If you try this out in React: ``` export default () => (

foo bar

) ``` You'll see that is behaves differently than in pure HTML: ```

foo bar

``` React ends up cropping out some more white space than I expected it to. **React** **Pure HTML** I haven't looked more into this, because I'm not sure it is actually a bug or a design choice. It is also not a super big problem, as far as I see it. I would be happy to look into it, if this was confirmed as a bug, though :) **What is the expected behavior?** I expected React to leave a white space between my text even if I break a line before an inline element (in my example a ``). In this case I would have to remove my line break for it to work. To illustrate, this works fine: ``` export default () => (

foo bar

) ``` So, when I checked in the console, I see the DOM created by React indeed trims out white spaces from the begining and the end of my string. The `nodeValue` for the `foo` text node in React is just that `nodeValue: "foo"` and in pureHTML it is `nodeValue: "\n foo\n "`. I should note that even if I add a space before the line break, it is still trimmed. **Which versions of React, and which browser / OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of React?** I don't know if this used to work, but currently I'm using MacOS Mojave, I have tested this in Firefox 67 and Chrome 72 and my React version is 16. --- _Sorry for the clumsy bug report, hope this helps._ :)
